awd_abstract_narration:
The PIPELINE Network project will significantly enhance physics education by developing and evaluating methods to incorporate workforce-relevant skills and activities in the student experience. The majority of physics graduates at all degree levels will become scientists and innovators working in the private sector, yet very little of the knowledge they gain while earning their degree specifically prepares them for these roles (for example, few physics programs emphasize real-world applications of scientific concepts, communication skills, or basic business concepts, all of which are important to successful private sector careers). Adding workforce-relevant learning to the discipline will attract a larger and more diverse student body to major in physics, and by extension improve the quality of the future STEM workforce. The PIPELINE project will bring together efforts of six institutions to create and document new approaches to teaching innovation and entrepreneurship in physics which can be shared with the broader community. The project will also advance our understanding of how these practices affect student and faculty attitudes towards innovation and entrepreneurship in physics.

The goals of the PIPELINE network are to build students' workforce confidence, improve physics faculty attitudes toward private sector careers, foster better integration of academic and industrial sectors, promote innovation in the physics discipline, and build a framework for wider adoption of physics innovation and entrepreneurship practices. The project will accomplish these by implementing physics innovation and entrepreneurship (PIE) approaches at member institutions during each year of the project, revising approaches between iterations, and finally documenting and disseminating curriculum. Most importantly, PIPELINE will develop surveys and interview protocols which will investigate the link between PIE experiences and student and faculty attitudes about innovation and entrepreneurship, and which can be used by other departments for gauging, monitoring, and improving institutional change around PIE. These research findings and tools will provide insights and utility that go beyond the immediate partner institutions, and live on beyond the duration of the project. PIPELINE will generate a core network of experienced PIE practitioners, a readily accessible body of tested PIE curricula deliberately varied in scope to fit unique needs and challenges of future adopters, and robust insight into the obstacles to PIE implementation and how future adopters might address them.

Project Outcomes Report:

Award Title: Collaborative Research: The PIPELINE Network

Federal Award ID: 1625089

This project was a collaboration between the American Physical Society (APS) and six institutions: Loyola University Maryland (Loyola), Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), Wright State University, University of Colorado-Denver, George Washington University, and The College of William and Mary. The goals of this PIPELINE Network were to create new approaches to teaching innovation and entrepreneurship in physics and to develop research instruments to investigate the link between such approaches and corresponding student and faculty attitudes. The project leaders developed and evaluated methods to incorporate workforce-relevant skills and activities into the student experience to enhance physics education, mapping these efforts onto four categories of learning outcomes: (1) physics-specific knowledge and skills; (2) scientific and technical skills; (3) communication skills; and (4) professional/workplace skills.

The project outcomes include physics career- and entrepreneurship-oriented pop-up courses, physics-focused makerspaces, and curriculum modules, all of which were implemented at the member institutions. All these materials (1) explicitly connect physics concepts with real-world applications; (2) utilize physics principles to create innovative solutions to real-world problems; and (3) include content relevant for careers in the private sector, such as communication skills, intellectual property protection, private and public funding sources, business models, budgeting, commercialization, and others. These curricula are freely available online to all educators

The PIPELINE Network project developed surveys and interview protocols to examine the link between PIE experiences and the attitudes of physics students and faculty about innovation and entrepreneurship. Based on student feedback in the related course evaluations, all educational materials have engaged undergraduate students in learning physics and fostered their interest in physics topics. Physics majors who participated in the project indicated that they had increased confidence that they were prepared to enter the workforce. In addition, over 80% of participating faculty reported benefits from the curriculum for both themselves and their students and 100% indicated that they would keep using the PIPELINE curricular materials after the project ended. The project results were presented at the 2019 and 2020 American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) Annual Conference, as well as presentations at other national conferences, invited talks, and workshops, and webinars.

The project generated a nascent and growing community of PIE practitioners. Faculty members across the six institutions participated in the project and revised courses with the PIE curricula, modules, and activities. Additionally, the project launched the PIE Newsletter and the EPIC web portal to share the results of the PIEPLIEN Network efforts with all educators and the public.
